poem:
Aztec Broccoli

In the soil's quiet hold,  
Sharon's gift of green,  
Not the common floret,  
A mystery unfolds unseen.  

Hope planted in rows,  
Beyond the diligent sun,  
Seek not the known,  
But wonders just begun.  

In gardens of myth,  
Life's whispered guise,  
Nature's dance,  
With ancient ties.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Heard of aztec broccoli? Let me tell you about my favourite new superfood ... | Adrian Chiles My neighbour Sharon was having no luck growing broccoli. So I gave up growing broccoli before I even started. If she couldn’t, I wouldn’t. Then she gave me six little plants, something called, mysteriously, aztec broccoli. It’s not actually broccoli, she told me. The plot thickened. Not being the kind of horticulturist who likes to get bogged down". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
